thread.title: The jewel-encrusted skeletons of Furstenfeld Abbey | Daily Mail Online
thread.title_full: The jewel-encrusted skeletons of Furstenfeld Abbey | Daily Mail Online

author: Annabel Fenwick Elliott For Mailonline
title: The jewel-encrusted skeletons of Furstenfeld Abbey | Daily Mail Online
text: Share 17 shares There, he was deliberately served with 'blessed' meat, which was banned by the Christian faith, and thus starved to death for refusing to eat it. The body identified as being his later found its way to Furstenfeld, which is a former Cistercian abbey. Saint Hyacinth (pictured), whose supposed skeleton is decked out with a dazzling crown and has a jewel-encrusted bottom jaw, died in 108 AD at the age of only 12 Posed in a slightly different manner but still boasting all the trimmings, the other skeleton (pictured) is said to belong to Saint Clemens, who died in Rome in 95 AD - beheaded for being a Christian The other skeleton, Saint Clemens, is thought to have died in Rome in 95 AD - beheaded for being a Christian. As for the abbey in which they are still venerated today, it has a somewhat morbid history of its own. It was built in the mid-1200s by Louis II, Duke of Bavaria, who was ordered to do so as penance for killing his first wife, by Pope Alexander IV. The two skeletons have been preserved here at the church as sacred full-body Christian relics for hundreds of years, encased in ornate glass cases. Pictured is the main altar Saint Clemens, whose gloved hand is arranged over his face as he lies on a stack of plush embroidered cushions Its first monks were sacked by the Swedes in the mid-1660s, but they later made a comeback. By the early 1800s the abbey was secularized along with the rest of Bavaria and passed into the private ownership - although its church continued to serve as a place of worship. Today, the elaborate building still holds Catholic services and is open to visitors. If you'd like to go and gaze and its prized skeletons yourself, guided tours cost only three euros (£2.50). These photos, taken by scientist Sue Anne Zollinger, display the church's intricate Baroque decor and imposing artwork Today, the elaborate place of worship still holds Catholic services and is open to visitors, with guided tours costing three euros (£2.50).
